Data point from over here:

The Abbot test suite (the framework automates GUI-related tests) runs 
anywhere from 70s to 20min, depending on the platform's AWT (general 
graphics subsystem, NOT just AWT widgets) support.

Many of the tests involve generating OS-level user input events, which 
by its very nature slows things down by an order of magnitude.  I 
usually have the full suite of tests running on one or more other 
platforms in order to parallelize the testing as well as ensure 
cross-platform consistency.

Test timing considerations aside, I think it'd be valuable to have a 
tool automatically track some sort of test levelization.  I am 
intimately familiar with the code, but I still don't keep *everything* 
in my head and when it comes to tracking complex interdependencies, the 
computer does (or should do) it much better than I can.  That's why 
we've got compilers, yes?

On Jul 19, 2004, at 6:11 AM, Chris Dollin wrote:

> On Saturday 17 July 2004 05:03, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>> Vlad Roubtsov wrote:
>>> On any but the trivial projects the number of
>>> testcases quickly exceeds 100-200+. It usually takes a
>>> noticeable time to run them all.
>>
>> Can you quantify this? GSBase, for example, runs tests at 
>> approximately
>> 100/second, and that's my usual performance goal for tests. On my most
>> recent project, I separated tests that required expensive, external
>> resources (there were about 10) from tests than ran entirely in memory
>> (there were about 400). The in-memory tests ran in about 6 seconds.
>>
>> Is this "noticeable" by your standards? I'd merely like some extra 
>> context.
>
> Data point from over here:
>
> Running the Jena test suite in Eclipse takes approx 50 seconds on my 
> 2Gb
> 3GHz machine. (Hmm, missing some stuff there - must sort out the
> proxy settings). More like 40s outside Eclipse (and with a working 
> proxy).
>
> I used to run with a 0.8GHz supposedly-dula processor and we were 
> talking
> more like 120s. (The database tests are separate and take 60s seconds
> to run, for mySQL on Linux at least - at one point it was more like 
> 20minutes,
> argh scream; I suspect there aren't enough of them.)
>
> The test suite is rather a hotchpotch, as it contains ancient tests 
> from
> before our more systematic use of JUnit which are more like acceptance
> tests than unit tests, but them's what we have. Usually I run the 
> tests for
> the bit I'm tinkering with at a moments provocation and run the full 
> suite
> when I reach some kind of anchor point - the necessity for loading or
> unloading tea, the final new feature working, or Oh My Stars Has It 
> Been
> An Hour?!
